comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Friedrich Franz Friedmann (1876-1953), German-born tuberculosis researcher; in 1913 he was noted for giving something called the "turtle vaccine" at his New York City clinic: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Franz_Friedmann

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Some searching in the NYT reveals that Friedmann was in the country from March through June 1913 and in the news frequently The turtle vaccine, Friedmann's intent to patent it , and his ethics were clearly controversial and the vaccine was banned by the New York Health Board on May 29, 1913 according to the NYT the next day. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C02E0DB143FE633A... The date on the stamp is March 24(?) 1913. An article on March 25, 1913 suggests he visited several hospitals that day: Hospital for Deformities and Diseased Joints (where the crowds to see him were noted), Mount Sinai, and Montefiore Home, query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C0CE5DD1F3AE633A... FRIEDMANN PATIENT DIES IN BELLEVUE; Prof. Ostrander, Treated on Friday, Expires from Tuberculosis of the Lungs and Kidneys.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: www.tevak.org/pdf/dergi/2007/pdfsno1/44_46.pdf is a history of the Hospital for Joint Diseases and has a picture circa 1910, which does not have such a staircase in evidence.
